text: OK, here we go.

One of my favorite things to
do is have my kids next to me

on the piano bench
and play together.
I grew up a musician.

I considered studying
music and becoming
a professional musician.

I ended up studying music
and neuroscience together.

One thing led to
another, and I decided

to focus on the basic
science of hearing.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I'm the founder
and CEO of Akouos.

Akouos is a company that's
trying to restore hearing

in children who were born
deaf due to mutations
in single genes.

Changes in these genes
resulted in inability
to make a certain protein.

And when that protein
isn't functioning properly,
a person isn't able to hear.

We think if we can get
a healthy copy of a gene

to the right cells
within the ear,

that there's an
opportunity in some cases

to restore the true
physiologic hearing.

In many cases, a
virus can function

as the vector, the
delivery vehicle

to get that gene of interest
into the right cell.

There's no way I'd be able to
do this without the Blavatnik
Fellowship.

Music was such an enriching
factor in my early life,

and I can see it
in my children, how

they respond to
music, how it can
bring a smile to their face.

But our ability to hear is much
more fundamental than that.

It's critical to our ability to
communicate with one another,

to perceive changes
in our environment.

I'm motivated to
do this every day,

because I think it
has the potential

to have a profound
impact on people's lives.
